newsitem.title: GERMANY: Tietmeyer says dollar correction now largely over.
newsitem.headline: Tietmeyer says dollar correction now largely over.

text.p: Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer said on Friday he sees the dollar's recent moves against the mark as a correction of the previously overvalued mark.
Tietmeyer said he views the dollar's correction as positive, but believes it is now largely over.

"The mark was in the past two years too strongly valued," Tietmeyer said in a radio interview on the eve of a meeting of finance ministers and central bankers from the Group of Seven industrialised nations.

"So recent moves are a correction, which by the way has also affected strong currencies such as the Swiss franc," he said. "So, overall, I think this a process that...is to be viewed very positively."
But Tietmeyer said he would not wish to see the opposite impression arising -- that the mark, or its planned Europe-wide successor the euro, would not be a strong currency over the long term.

"I believe the correction process has now largely come to an end," he said. "We will do everything we can to ensure that the mark, as long as we have the mark, remains a stable currency and that the euro will become a stable currency, measured against the mark."
